Review Title: Peaceful and spiritual experience for couples
Review Text: We visited Kalutara Bodhiya during our trip to the south coast and it turned out to be one of the most peaceful stops of our journey. The temple is beautifully located by the Kalu River, and the huge white stupa looks amazing from the main road. What makes it special is that you can actually go inside the stupa and see lovely wall paintings that tell Buddhist stories. As a couple, we really enjoyed the calm and spiritual atmosphere it was a nice break from the beach and the traffic. We sat quietly for a few minutes just taking in the surroundings and watching locals bring flowers and offerings. dress modestly, remove your shoes before entering, and only give donations at the official box. There were a few people near the entrance offering “tours” for money, but it’s best to politely decline. We went around 4:30 pm, and the light was beautiful for photos, especially with the river and sunset in the background. Highly recommend a short visit if you’re passing through Kalutara peaceful, cultural, and a lovely shared moment for couples.

Review Title: Peaceful Spiritual Spot by the River A Must Visit in Kalutara
Review Text: We visited the Kalutara Bodhiya during our stay in Kalutara and were truly moved by its peaceful and spiritual atmosphere. This sacred Buddhist temple is built around one of the 32 saplings of the original Sri Maha Bodhi tree in Anuradhapura, making it a very important site for local worshippers. The white stupa (dagoba) is unique because you can actually walk inside it, which is quite rare in Buddhist temples. Inside, there are beautiful murals and statues depicting the life of the Buddha. The entire area is clean, well-maintained, and offers a calm, respectful environment. Located right by the Kalu Ganga (river), the setting is very picturesque especially at sunset. It’s a great place to reflect, take in some history, or simply enjoy the peaceful surroundings. We also appreciated that it wasn’t overcrowded when we went in the late afternoon.

Review Title: Peaceful Hidden Gems and an Amazing Kalutara Temple Experience
Review Text: We had an amazing experience with Hai Sri Lanka Tours! Before starting our main tour, our guide Sithum and driver Dilan took us to a local hidden gem early in the morning. It was stunning and peaceful, with almost no crowd, making it a perfect start to our day. One of the highlights of our tour was visiting Kalutara Temple. The temple is incredibly beautiful and serene, with impressive architecture and a calm atmosphere that makes it perfect for reflection and photography. The surroundings are well-kept, and the temple offers a glimpse into Sri Lanka’s rich cultural and spiritual heritage. Highly recommend visiting if you want a peaceful and memorable experience.

Review Title: A Peaceful and Historic Experience at Kalutara Bodhiya
Review Text: A trip to Kalutara Bodhiya was an unforgettable experience. This temple is not only a religious site but also a cultural and historical monument. With Hai Srilanka Tours, I had the opportunity to observe beautiful Buddhist statues, paintings, and traditional buildings, while learning a great deal about the religious and historical significance of the place. Our guide, Sithum, explained everything to us in detail. No admission fee – free for all, though donations are welcome. Around 1–2 hours is the best to see and absorb the atmosphere.The temple atmosphere is serene and spiritual. You feel peace and positivity as soon as you enter.It is crowded during weekends, poya days (full moon), and religious festivals, but weekdays are quite emptier and peaceful.The staff and monks were friendly and courteous, politely guiding visitors on customs and prayers.This is the best place for anyone looking to experience Sri Lankan culture, Buddhism, and history. It is most appropriate for families, singles, and groups looking for an enrichment experience.

This is a beautiful temple. Be sure to climb up the stairs into the stupa (the large dome structure) and enjoy the views of the region. For an interesting little-known peaceful meditation place, cross the street into the other temple complex and find the building with a bodhi tree in a small courtyard. The building has a stone bench that surrounds the courtyard, and is a great place to meditate.

Our tok tok Driver took us  here for the day. He also came into the temple with us. You do have to cover your legs if you’ve got shorts on, but the lady at reception gave me a lovely white sarong to cover myself with, everybody in the temple is wearing white. It’s lovely to watch the locals going about their day and praying to Buddha. you can also then go underground to the other side where there’s the massive dome which you can go inside and walk around and there are paintings around the wall of buddha , well worth the visit.

Review Title: Glad we visited. Lovely temple site
Review Text: Glad we did a tut tut tour that included going to visit this temple site. Really serene, calm place. Beautiful artwork and easy to walk around and look at everything. It's on both sides of the road with a walkway (subway) under the road. I enjoyed our visit.

Review Title: Mind Relaxing Temple Located in Heart of the City Kaluthara
Review Text: One of the Most peaceful and beautiful Temple in Lanka and when you pass kaluthara junction from Galle road , this is must visit place,  this is one of the few temples which can go inside the Sthupaha.  inside the sthupa we can see and explore the outside area from glass windows. and temple are was spread other side of the road we can cross the Galle road through under road tunnel. wear suitable clothes when visit there. in poyaday and weekend crowded. no need to buy tickets to enter temple,

Very authentic place, pleasant aromas of incense, beautiful details and one of the best and largest bodhias of Sri Lanka. It's better not to come on Sunday, so there'll be fewer people. And it's better to go with a guide who will tell you about the traditions of their religion!

A world famous Buddhist temple in Kalutara. This temple is situated on the Galle road, therefore its a very busy & crowded place. Be cautious when crossing the road as its by the side of a very busy road. Much revered place by Buddhists, but it will be an interesting place for others too. Parking of vehicles will be  a little away from the temple.

The temple is an interesting building of Buddhist culture. You can get a little interesting insight into this culture. The entrance is for free, donations are welcome. Of course you should be respectful to Buddhist Religion and behave like it is suitable for a religious monument. Then you get a little feeling of the spirit of this place.

Well the temple I saw many times when went tuk-tuk. Near temple is located flower market. By the way opposite bus station was my favorite tea shop. They have different high quality tea: black tea, orange pekoe, green tea, fruit tea, herbal
You park on the other side of the bridge and cross the bridge, the temple is very beautiful both inside and outside. However it is worth a visit
It is much crowded during poya days and Sundays. So if you want to relax your mind and go for peace of mind, avoid those days. Parking is available a bit far off the bridge.
Most Buddhist visit the shrine on their way to down south , one important items is that it has an under ground leading to other side of the road.

It is a Buddhist shrine located in the Kalutara District of the Western Province .It has an architecturally unique Dagaba. A beautiful and clean shrine where maintenance is well done.It is located near the Kalu Ganga. It consists of two sections on either side of the road and is connected by a short underground tunnel.With a peaceful environment and historical value, this shrine is a must visit place for tourists.
Kalutara Bodhiya is a Bodhi tree located in kalutara western province of sri lanka. Kalutara bodhi can be considered as a famous place among all the tourists attractions.

When you travel srilanka you must visit this temple at kalutara. this is a different kind of sthupa. you can go inside of the sthupa and sea arround the island. you can sea the beautiful kalutara beach from there.
At nice very clam and nice place. So beautiful in the evening . Buddhist secret place in kalutara...
This is a popular  Buddhist temple in Srilanka. All the vehicles stop here while going past and the drivers pray for  a safe journey.

One of the most recognized places in Kalutara specifically among buddhists. Situated either side of the Colombo Galle main road. Has a scenic view adding to it’s religious importance. One of the rare places where you find a ‘chithya’ inside another and you can walk inside it

Kalutara Bodhiya is a sacred temple for Buddhist and you can find many devotees every day. It is located just beside the Kalu Ganga (river). Walk on the bridge and get into the Temple. Temple has two sections either sides of the road and connected by a short underground tunnel. Make sure to visit both sides. ENTRANCE FREE

As a part of my sons school trip we visited this place. Kaluthara Temple is located at both side of the road. It’s around 1.5 hrs from Colombo. The Upper Bodhiya is a sprout from the Sri Maha Bodhiya at Anuradhapura. This temple is believed to be belongs to the 2nd century
One of the most sacred buddhist temples in Sri Lanka. Surrounding is always peaceful. A must visit for a visitor.
It is really claimed and cool religious place in Kalutara city. The Bo-tree has historical value too. You can see the nice view out there with Kalugaga river and the sea.
very clam and quite place.also very secret place.people believe it has power . Very secret place for buddhist

Iconic place of the Kalutara city also Kalutara district in Sri Lanka. This Buddhist place is maintain by Kalutara Bodhi Trust. It's first chairman was Sir Cyril De Soyza who founded this place. Special thing is the large and beautiful Dagoba can enter the inner side to view and worship who need to go there.

This place is one of the most important places in sri lanka and to the Buddhist culture. Lots of things to see, and learn,  in here you have a rear chance of walking in to a giant pagoda. An Amazing Place, Highly Recommend
This is the main Buddhist hub of Kalutara with 2 "BO" Trees . Calm  , peacefull spiritual relaxing religious place for who loves to visit. Please dress white dress with full covered your body.
a new temple not interesting at all. very big but it was not interesting to visit it. people is very spiritual in Sri Lanka...this is interesting...

We enjoyed visiting this interesting temple - really interesting. It was very busy. As is often the case you need to be dressed appropriately - ladies are provided with shoulder covering. Shoes must be left at the entrance - not good for those with tender feet as there are many rough surfaces or stones

Definitely worth a visit as this is a rare opportunity to go inside a stoupa. There is a stoupa inside the stoupa, and a series of paintings which tell the story of Buddha, The Stoupa is part of a larger temple site which is well attended by locals.
An interesting insight to the Bhuddist faith. The stupor is hollow. Ask a local to tell you what is happening. The people are very friendly and helpful
A nice religious place with a lovely surrounding. The architecture is superb. I really loved the scent of the fragrance sticks :D
Only saw this temple from the road. Very impressive and very popular. Many people stop to pray outside the temple.
Peaceful but huge. The big temple has an ancient bodi tree and a stupa dome that you can enter. Inside there is a smaller stupa and artwork showing the life and teaching of Budda.
This is the main buddhist temple in Kalutara area. Close to city centre. Easy access. By the the river .

The majority of Sri Lankans (82%) are Buddhist and every where you go you come across great Buddhist temples. This is a must for any traveller who wishes to experience the rich teachings of Lord Buddha
Nice to see & experience the way of Buddhist shrines. The way of building is attractive. Great view with the river
Visited the Bodhiya on Christmas day. It was a festive place where there was a lot of worshippers giving thanks and prayers to the Buddha in the Bodhiya temple.

Great monument to visit. Amazing combination of sea, river, green Boo tree and White pagoda. One of the must place to visit when you are at Kalutara and you can climb the large Pagoda and you will find real serenity inside the amazing Pagoda.
One of the iconic Buddhist temple located at Kalutara (next to galle road). This temple is famous for the Bo tree located in it and pictures at the inside of the sthuppa.
We visited this lovely religious place during our stay in Kadutara & it was a very nice experience go to inside of a Stupa!
Nice and Huge Temple in Kaluatara, Sri Lanka. Go and visit. Remove your shoes before enter. It was little bit crowded when we visit.
has to walk about 50 m from the car park to bodiya. nice view from the temple. kalu ganga can see widely.

Got five tuk tuks into kalutara as a trip to town went temple and was fascinated by the architectural parts of it was clean and very welcoming then into the shop part can haggle get good bargains if need

The minute you arrive some local will approach you . Pretending to be a guide. When you give the lady your shoes keep the tag ,otherwise he will try and charge you at the end . But it’s all free!! Let him take you around he will explain it and show you where to go . But do not give him the donation at the end ,put it in the box yourself when collecting your shoes . We just gave him a very small token of £1 . You should have your arms and legs covered . But it was interesting.

A beautiful place located in a river bank where you can spend some time with peace of mind. However, better to go there in a less crowded day, otherwise you wont be able to indulge in that serene feeling. A must visit place if you are around Kalutara
Was taken around by our tuk tuk driver tree full of fruit bats and Buddha life story in picture around inside of dome. Well worth a visit if in the area
Most of the times i visited kalutara bodi.it is a calm and quate  religious place.i invite all to worship kalutara bodi
Lot of local prayers there in every day , it's very nice architectural design , you can go inside of the temple and see it. River is beside the temple. Parking area is very big , easy access.

It is well worth stopping at the Kalutara Bodhiya if passing through. This historic temple and people from the area were instrumental in promoting the Buddhist revival during colonial times under the British.

I have visited Kaluthara Bodhiya many times, where I enjoy the religious rituals and Sri Lankan culture of Buddhist society. Great place for Buddhist photography. Part of the temple is facing the kaluthara river. and the other part is next to the rail track. You will get the best view from the north. You can reach there by train or road and very calming environment.
A must stop and visit and donate money for its upkeep as it is genuine.A unique dago a as you can visit it’s inside which no other dagoba has.

Poya is the full moon holiday that occurs every month. The Bodiya is the only dome temple that allows entry and people come from far and wide. Beware the guides solicit donations for a food drive and to be fair there is a donations office along with a shoe store for foreigners footwear. Well worthwhile and rewarding

This venerated temple has a prestigious history emanating back to the early colonial period. Once known as the Gangathilake temple, It was destroyed by the Portuguese to build a formidable fort to control cinnamon trade. It is now a most visited temple in Sri Lanka. The Bodhi (Fig tree) is known as a sapling of Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi of Anuradhapura

Buy you flowers from the vendor outside and make a wish inside . Climb the stairs and at the top is a huge circular domed room with paintings depicting the birth of Buddhism . My knowledge of the religion was limited so enjoyed it . I biked from the nearby Anantara , dual carriageway with tuk tuks lorries buses and cars weaving about made it an interesting experience too ! 😀

If you have thirty minutes or an hour to spend in Kalutara, go to the temple! Dress well: knees and shoulders covered. Sit at the Bodhi tree and watch the locals preform their rituals. The main stupa also has additional information on the life of lord Buddha. Just watch out for swindlers.

While visiting Kalutara we went to this temple , a very pleasant feel place , one can see lot of devotees offering prayer to Lord Buddha by sitting around the Temple. It’s on both side of road and is connected by Sub way . You can climb the stupa and see the upper storey and offer prayer..

This Bodiya said to be one of 32 samplings obtained from Sacred Sri Maha Bodiya at Anuradapura (A sapling from Original Bodi Tree Lord Buddha stayed for cover when he became enlightened), during same time as it was planted. But what is more prominent is the giant Dagoba or Chaithya lately built close to it and some consider it to be the best recently built such structure in Sri Lanka, but crowded on many days with locals due to its proximity to Town, Colombo and Main Galle Road. If you are heading towards Galle using Old Galle Road (Not Southern Highway), better not to miss. Even clearly noticeable  from Road.

Temple was crowded by pilgrims. But we were able to worship both side temples. The dagaba was unique. It was not made like other ones. It was not solid.  You can walk inside. Other side of the road you will find the famous Ananda Bodiya. Which is historically sacred place. People say Your wishes will come true if you worship this sacred place. Parking was situated off the bridge towards colombo side. You have to walk along the bridge. If you traveling towards south via Galle road when you passing this sacred place don’t forget to worship. It will make your trip successful.
I went early evening to pray, it was absolutely stunning and serene even though it was quite busy with others praying

Worth a visit - but don't get caught into paying for a guild through the temple, its free. They may ask you to donate for milk money for the babies however they then ask for 1700 Rupees !!!! Not really a lot of money but its how its done.
I am Christian  but hotel  arranged  me city  tour to Bodhiya temple..The was very clean and neat. People  over  there are more  helpful for the foreigners..

The kalutara bodiya is one of the religious place which is venerated by all buddhist in sri lanka. anybody who comes from colombo or galle stop over at the sacred shrine to pay their respects by way of worshipping and offerings. here is a hollow dagoba with interesting paintings. during 2nd century ad the ven. mahinda thera has directed that 32 saplings taken from the sri mahabodhiya be planted at certain points around the country it is believed that the present bo-tree in kalutara is supposed to be one of the 32 saplings of sri maha bodiya. the kalutara bodiya is located just after the kalutara river from the colombo side.
it is a bhuddist temple. If you want to visit the temple u should wear a dress below knee lenght. otherwise u will not b allowed to go inside .

While you have to deal with the scorching floors barefoot, the serene silent and calming areas around this temple on both sides of a main road let you know what life is truly about. Spend time here to experience internal bliss and sites the soul will appreciate. Leave energized.
If you have time for sightseeing,you will find not more options in this region. You fill find some paintings around the interior space which are related tonbudhists myths.

You can not miss it, if you are travelling from Colombo to Galle. It is huge structure painted in white. We could not go inside because of the space between the place for taking off the shoes and the temple entrance is having beach-like sand. So we could not take off our shoes, as it was very hot.  It may be suggested that this gap is covered with titles or grass.
its very beautiful and one of the very ancient and important buddhist pagoda to visit. ancient paintings to see. i recommended you to visit on the way to down south

Very nice temple, makes a nice photo opportunity. Very clean and well maintained. Lots of locals both inside and outside praying and many people selling flowers for you to take in. Very peaceful place.

Clean place, busy with dedicated locals praying. You can buy flowers before you go in. People carry their lamp burning accessories/incense sticks. Cross the road via an underpass & you come to the main temple with its huge pagoda, visible from a distance. It is one of the few attractions in the area & was nice to visit. I believe this temple too has a lot of significance for Buddhists. Even when passing by, they bow their heads & many stop & drop a donation in the many boxes placed by the pavement.

Whether you follow Buddhism or not, this place is really worth seeing. It is important to go to both sides of the road via the underpass to see the whole complex. We found everyone very welcoming. It is always very busy but they seem to keep it clean despite large numbers of people. Car parking is difficult. The views from the top of the large pagoda are worth the climb up the stairs.
We visited as part of a trip around Kalutara, this is a lovely temple, very peaceful. Well worth a visit, especially as you can walk up into the dome

Who ever goes to this place despite of religion will fall in love as it's absolutely a best location. The Kalu river and the beach lagoon and the railway and mail road from all this place get the amazing view that you can get pleasurable scenery.

Buddhism is a very historical and important place for visit. Inside main temple you able to go inside and do any religious activities. If you need to get relaxed to your mind please go there and stay few hours

I was curious to see how buddhist celebrate a holy day. It was a nice experience for me ( the first one ). I was impressed by the gentleness of the people and amused about children openness and curiosity.
A good place to visit to understand local culture and beliefs. Photography is a must. Carry your camera aat all times.
As everybody knows Kaluthara Temple is one of the highlight and secret Buddhist temple in Srilanka. easy stop and worth visit for anyone passing Colombo - Galle (A2) road
Wonderful! We experienced the evening prayers. very welcoming. Visitors need to cover their legs before entering the temple.
Visited this temple with a large stupa while staying in Kalutara. It's very nice and quiet place despite being on both sides of a busy road.
Quite a large complex with underpass to reach main temple. Do not accept any offers from guides. Even though it's banned!

A nice temple to visit but I wouldn't go out of your way to do so Once inside there isn't a huge amount to see Shoes must be removed before you climb the stairs but they can be safely stored Donations only required

Worth a look if you are Kalutara as it is one of the few things to do in the centre as a tourist. As in all Buddhist temples visitors must remove their shoes and there is a lady who looks after your shoes whilst you visit. There is a "discretionary" donation for entry and for looking after your shoes. The ground was quite rough so wasn't the easiest to walk on if like us you don't walk barefoot outside very often. Inside there are four Buddha statues to view which aren't particularly ornate.
Kalutara Bodhiya is an old Bodhi tree which is identified as one of the 32 saplings of Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi which was planted during the reign of king Devanampiyatissa

WE have visited Kalutara Bodhiya On the way to Bentota Beach Hotel when our daughter, son in Law and granddaughter visited to Sri Lanka from Melbourne Australia  in June 2016. Kalutara Bodhiya situated in Kalutara at a side of the Galle Road. Those days there was a big Bannion tree (nuga Tree) at the entrance of Kalutara all the vehicles had to go under the Banion tree. Some time back the tree was broken down due to weather and now there is no sign of the tree. All most all the vehicles pass near the Kalutara Bodhiya donate some money to the Bodhiya and also conductors of the public transport collect money from the people who like to donate  and put the collected money in the till which is constructed on the wall of the Bodhiya. Kalutara Bodhiya is an old Bodhi tree which is identified as one of the 32 saplings of Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi which was planted during the reign of King Devanampiyatissa in the 2nd century BC at Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. Now there is a viharaya built opposite to the Bodhiya. In side the viharaya there are statues of the lord Buddha.Every day lots of people visited the Bodhiya and the Viharaya. During Full moon days the Bodhiya and Viharaya full of people who observed sil.This is one of the attractions in Kalutara and travelers who are going down South should stop there and visit the viharasya which is opposite to the Bodhiya.

Visited the temple with a friend from Sri Lanka, I found it a very moving and spiritual experience. A very beautiful place.  There is no entrance fee to the temple but you can make a donation. If you are visiting Kalutra this is a must on you list of places to visit.
Nice, but quite like any other temples. People are not very friendly, looking at tourists like troublemakers.

Spectacular site! Wonderful huge stupa and temple with beautiful views of the surrounding river and railway / vehicular bridges - and no horrifically overpriced (and discriminatory) entry fees and touts. So serene! A must-visit place!

we stayed at the Avani spa and resolt in Katutara .The hotel is on a the beach and other side looks over a lagoon. The staff are so friendly and the food excellent. we stayed on a half board basis. I payed extra for a romantic meal for two on the beach and we were totally spoilt . We would really recommend this to any couples with a romantic side.

One of the most secret Buddhist places in Sri Lanka and a must visit place if you are travelling in Sri Lanka. Situated glamorously on the shores by the Kalu Ganga the Kalutara Bodhiya is a Spectacular side and one of the most visited temples of Sri Lanka. Daily thousands of devoted Buddhist come to pay homage and get bless and to offer flowers, incent stick and light oil lamps to worship The Lord Buddha and the Stupa. Its on the way to down South of Sri Lanka and situated about an hour away from Colombo in the Galle in Kalutara.

Went there twice. First time, on a full moon night. Got to experience something very local which was absolutely amazing. Must to inside the temple too. Also walk around the bridge, see the train passing. People are so friendly here.
This is a place one can easily accessible located around 40 km from Colombo. This is a wonderful scenic location blessed by the famous bodhi tree which is one of 32 saplings of Sri Maha Bodhi.

Worth a visit but wouldn't make a special journey.  The frieze in the Bodhiya detailing the life of the Buddha is interesting and the area where the stupa is situated has a number of beautiful shrines dedicated to various deities. You are required to cover your knees and shoulders so ensure you go prepared. You are also required to remove your shoes and some of the ground is quite rough.

Such a tranquil place in the town of Kalutara. One gets a sense of fulfilment when inside the temple. So serene and peaceful. There Bodhiya has two places on either side of the road and on the banks of the river. The inside of the place is huge with a white dome. Lovely place to pray in peace.

One of the gretest temple in recently build very famous among travellers.locals who travells south put donation to get blessings.beauty because of it's massive Stupa and Old Bo tree.Stupa is great because can climb inside.inside can fide lot's of paintings belong to story of Budda.
We were lucky enough to see this during the festival it was amazing everything was lite up and people were everywhere really loved being apart of this
A place of visit of all Buddhists. One of the many places Sri Lankan Buddhists stop by/visit who are traveling on the Galle-Colombo main road.
Nice and peaceful place to be, nothing special about this place. Can visit en route while going to other places

Visited by many buddhists in the country and famous among both local and foreign. The place gets very crowded during buddhist religious festival days and this is one of the temples in sri lanka that has access to the bodhiya inside..

I really enjoyed visiting this place. It was very spiritual. I know very little about Buddhism but tried to learn during my visit to Sri Lanka. From what I could gather, there is the stupa one one side of the road, which you can go inside as it is so large and hollow, and the other, older Buddhist temple or viharaya on the other side. Of course there is also the Bo tree. There is a lot of history and culture here, so make sure you see it all. Don't just visit the stupa, even though it's architecture alone is amazing. Soak up the culture, look around, listen to the locals who have come to worship here. You'll take more away from the experience that way.

A really nice location by the river on the edge of a busy road. Large picturesque Stupa. Very quiet when we visited.  Small but really interesting frescoes of the life of Buddha. Take a nice tuk tuk journey to it. Would not make a special journey to visit it, a nice stop over.
It's  one of the  great  places in  Kalutara. Beautiful  location  on the  river, bridge make it  looks  nice during the day  and  at night. Close to the  temple  bus stop. I  recommend to visit.
Easy going calm 2hr vist.Temple easy to locate,no queues and followers eagerly willingly to share their beliefs.
We were there at national day, so there were many people and we were the only tourists. But everyone was very friendly and we got a good insight into the culture. Definitely worth a visit!

We were staying at at the Cinnamon Bey Hotel, Behruwala. My driver/guide suggested we visit the Kalutara Bodhiya as it is one of the only Buddhist temples where you can enter inside the Stupa. We had to park the car and walk through a tunnel under the road to get to this temple. Very peaceful temple. What amazed me were the beautiful paintings around the wall which told the story of Lord Buddha. The Kalutara River is also has good scenery. Definitely worth the time we spent visiting this place.
So many people come for kalutara bodiya. kalutara river is by the side of bodiya. There is small tunnel to cross the road. This is very useful for pilgrims. The big stupa is other side of the road.

I visited the bodhiya with my family. Very tranquil and nice, despite the busy traffic on Galle Road. I recommend entering the bodhiya through the underground tunnel instead of crossing the road. I always try to buy my flowers from the old flower sellers near the bodhiya. A must see/visit place if passing by Kalutara.
This is  one of the most beautifully painted temple's with the story of Buddha painted round the dome we have ever seen , definitely worth a visit.
Enough of parking before the Bodhiya when you visit from colombo side. But on a poya day this will be crowded. More valuable place for Buddhist people. "Kalugana" is beside the Bodhiya.
Not very far from the Hotel with Tuk Tuk !! Only Rupies 300 one way to the City Kalutara. One can also reach this town with Train from Turyaa Kalutara Hotel.
If you go to Sri Lanka it is a must, very nice temple and wonderful feeling and never seen so many Lotus Flower.
As luck would have it we visited on the full moon festival so the temple was like a hive of activity. Plenty of lotus flowers sellers, incense sellers and lots of drums and noise. Very atmospheric.
As with most of Sri Lanka all the Buddhists respect and honour the shrine at Kalurara everyone stops and pays respect at the shrine just as we did a quite humbling experience
This place was a really nice stop. The buildings  were simple yet beautiful I recommend this place if you have some time.
A place with a rich history dated as far as the arrival of Lord Buddha to Sri Lanka. Most sacred item was the Sacred Bo Tree.
If you are visiting Colombo and are interested in Buddhist temples, this is one of the main places to visit. It has a large stupa which you can enter, a rarity in Sri Lanka.
In busy down town. First Buddhist tmple. Not the prettiest by far thiugh. There are many more beautidul ones to see.
great country amazing things to see,good food ,lovely people,a must place to visit. great beaches ,to the tea plantations in the north.

The Kalutara Bodhiya and the Stupa is located on either side of a busy road in Kalutara. The Stupa and the Bhodi Tree are an absolute must visit for any tourist. They are both located about 40 minutes out of Colombo, heading south at the mouth of the Kalu Ganga (river). The location itself is wonderfully picturesque. However the real treat is when you visit the actual Stupa as it is a white 3 storey high stupa that is uniquely hollow, allowing visitors to enter it, or even walk around the inside of it, or sit on the floor and just experience the peaceful atmosphere within. The larger stupa actually contains a smaller Stupa inside. The interior of the Stupa is decorated with paintings of the life of the Buddha. Then across the road from the Stupa is the Kalutara Bodhiya which is said to be another sapling grown from the original Bodhi Tree that is still living in Anuradhapura. Both these sites are very popular with all Sri Lankans. Therefore, you will find that both sites will be packed with devotees either just stopping-off before embarking on a long journey, or visiting for the day, or visiting and meditating perhaps for the day or even longer. When we visited, both sites were as usual very busy. The whole site had a very pleasant and peaceful energy. We observed many ladies at the Stupa praying or meditating around the site. We also entered the Stupa and walked around the inside, viewing all the paintings on the walls. While we were there, we observed a young man meditating and chanting Buddhist scriptures, in a very melodic tone, which seemed to reverberate around the whole Stupa. What a wonderful experience it was.
The huge stupa is unique we were told in that it is one of the few that can be entered into. It has depictions of the Buddhas life and a view of the surrounding from its height.
Relics were stored in a chamber, so we didn't see them, but the painted walls depicting the life of Buddha and his influence on the Sri Lankan king was interesting.

This is on of the biggist budhiya temple on the Sri Lanka island. All the time so many local people come to this place and pray. When you go to any temple - you must to take your shoes off a cover knees a shoulders.When you do this, you are free to go into the temple.
This is an important place for buddhists. View is nice. Remove shoes before you enter. There is a place to keep them safe.

We visited the temple of the tooth and found it absolutely crazy not what you would expect to find in a Buddhist temple extremely busy and loud . This temple on the other hand is exactly what you would expect . Peaceful , thought provoking and beautiful. you walk anywhere and feel at ease and the smells are phenomenal.  1 tip for anyone going , buy incense at a local vendor to instantly transport back there once home
Kalutara bhodiya is a one of largest temple  in sri lanka. With a historical background and the beach sorrounding is beautiful.

You can't miss this edifying edifice - wherever you are in Kalutara. It's a lot newer than it looks, especially after the brilliant white paint job it was undergoing during our visit. However, it's no less colourful for that. Remember to take small change to pay them to look after your shoes.
Kalutara bodhisattva is one of the main Buddhist attractions and a religious destination in Sri Lanka and the history behind this stupa will take you to many centuries.
Its a place for Buddhist to worship and pray, when you go there its essential to wear long cloths white or pale colored.no head ware allowed. peaceful place to relax and calm the soul down.
Interesting and clean bigger than it looks this is still in use and local people are always there praying
A very interesting temple to pray and understand a bit more about Buddhism. Just avoid the solicitations.
Probably better to see the Kalutara Bodhiya as part of seeing other sights unless you plan to meditate for a while or just sit and and enjoy the peace.

If you seek relaxation and calmness to your mind, no other better place than this to do the job. Peaceful enviornment and will feel worldless emotions when you come out of this sacred place. Must visit place if you explore Kalutara area.

The temple itself is very beautiful and well worth a visit just beware of the guides !!!! We were well and truly conned by one of the unscrupulous men. We arrived at the shrine opposite the temple and were met by a guide!!!! He was very informative and showed us round the shrine then took us beneath the underpass and demanded 2000rupees from each of us !!!! We didn't have much choice but to pay it he was very demanding. We then left him and went into the temple making a donation. This experience upset the rest of day. So please be aware of these horrible people who use a place of worship to extract money from you. We will not make the same mistake again !!

we were at there,memorable places in our vacation . lot of tourists will visit this important  place. Kaluthara bodiya is located in a very nice area beside the Kalu Ganga.it was the 4th highist river in sri lanka.
Visited while staying at Kalutara. Car park is further than expected. Temple was less crowded since it was a weekday. The underground tunnel is a safe way to cross to the other side of the temple.
Kaluthara Bodiya is one of the best place to visit, mostly tourists will visit this holy place. Kaluthara bodiya is located in a very nice area beside the Kalu ganga (River)

We visited this temple out of season so it was fairly quiet inside. Buddha sits in the centre of the dome and on the walls of the dome are paintings of the Buddha story. There is no entry fee though a donation is welcomed. We visited the shrine over the road first where a guide (?!) wanted to charge us $30 to take us to the Bodhiya so beware.
Its a buddhist temple.Well it was a different experience.The place is peaceful and you cannot wear cap and shoes inside.

Lovely peaceful temple; nice escape from the chaos! Remember to take your shoes off before you go in. I wouldn't make a long journey to visit this temple, however if you are less than 30 minutes away then give it a go!
Made a brief visit to this Buddhist temple. It was very impressive, the local people were very accommodating.

One of the most venerated place in sri Lanka .it is famous for its pagoda which is one of the uniqni creation in sri lanka .unlike other pagoda in the country it is hollow in side and painted with stories relating to the past lives of lord Buddha.they are very elegant paintings.its architecture is associated  with the world famous civil engineer Dr H N S Kulasinghe of pre fabricated concrete fame.

We had a very nice tour guide that gave us a tour around the whole complex. Place is very fascinating and i would recommend visiting. Reminder: You do have to take off your shoes when entering a religious area.
We were allowed in this temple that signposted no guides no fee. The uniqueness of the place is the done that is hollow and can be entered. A good place to ponder

we had travelled past Kalutara Bodhiya and thought it beautiful but felt abit self concious going in on our own...we really shouldn't have worried a lovely gentleman showed us around and took extra care to explain his belies and the amazing temple to our daughter. he helped her light and oil lamp and even gave her flowers for her hair. our daughter took it all very seriously and everyone was lovely with us all.yes we were expected to tip on our leaving, but after all the time taken with us it was really a pleasure giving to help this incredible place .
Large monolithic buildings like these really attract me and the open space provided the perfect space for the devoted.

The Kaluthara Bodhiya is located in between the ocean and one of the main river in Sri lanka, it names Kalu Ganga. This place is very calm. Everyday many buddhist people come here and worshiped. And also we can go inside of the Big Stupa and there is a another small stupa for worship to the people. This Place is nice see who are traveling in Sri lanka.
Nice calm place. Buddhist people come and worshiped kalutara bodhiya. More people visit and worshiped this wonderful calm palce
one of the places i visited during my stay in Sri Lanka, worth seeing. had a tale of history. first view was from the bridge and then decided to go closer.

This special pagoda is unique compared to any others in the world and most respected one for Buddhist.   Located in between the Indian ocean and the One of the main river (Kalu) in Srilanka. Nice and calm place for meditation and longest walking path for meditation also available.

I thought this place was hundreds of years old. The drawings on the ceiling are stunning. Well worth a visit so quiet inside and well looked after. Put donations in the yellow bins or take into the office and they will give a receipt.
This place is so nice and quiet. We spent there very nice time during some celebration. Monks are so kind.

You can't miss the Kalutara Bodiya (Dagoba) if you are driving on the normal Colombo to Galle route, it's a magnificent Buddhist temple where millions of people venerate every year, the evening light ceremony is the best time to view it, it is one unique Dagoba where one can enter in to the belly of the Dagoba which is very rare in other temples, the Bo tree on the opposite side with a golden fence is a highly religious place where people go to engage in pooja, must stop if you pass by here.. Rohan Jayamanna

Loved it 😁 Great way to see budist temple. It's located on the banks of Kalutara river. So peaceful and so much to learn about the budism. Every one in our family enjoyed. Definitely one place to visit if you are going down south.
we were taken to this temple by our tour guide buddika when we were on our way to galle.i learnt so much of thing from this visit,

This one is more different than all other stupa's. This one is pure And not seen by lot of tourist. There are several Boeddha statues. Also THE area arround this place is nice u Can see THE beach view from upstairs.
Very interesting. If you are a Buddhist this place is a must go. Even if you aren't there is a lot to see and experience about Buddhism and Sri Lankan culture over there.

We travelled on a tuk-tuk from our hotel in Kalutara to the Bodhiya Temple. You enter on one side of the road. There is no entrance fee but you have to leave your footwear and it is expected that you give a small tip to the staff keeping your shoes safe. It is a good idea to wear an old pair of socks to protect your feet as you visit the site. There are a few small buildings, including one brightly coloured Buddha on this side of the road. Then you travel via a tunnel under the busy main road to the site of the main temple. You pass many flower sellers and have to climb a considerable number of steps before you can enter the main dome. Uniquely, this is not solid but hollow. When you reach the top level inside, you can survey 360 degrees of town, countryside and river through the windows which go round the inside of the dome. Above the windows are a large number of paintings of the Buddha, his life and travels. The atmosphere is enhanced by the throng of pilgrims and people praying. So many sights catch the eye. I was amazed how some quite aged and badly crippled worshippers bravely climbed the large number of steps to reach the prayer hall and the main dome. It is certainly a very worthwhile place to visit.
One of the best little temples we saw in Sri Lanka , well maintained and we were able to take all the beauty of it. Well worth a visit
One of famous Buddhist temples in Sri Lanka situated in Kalutara near River Kalu. One of specialty of this Sthupa is you can go inside of it.

One of the first eight samplings of Sri Maha Bodhi planted here. All the respect should goes to Sir Syril Soyza for present conditions of the place. This large concrete dome shell structure was designed by Dr. A. N. S. Kulasinghe of the State Engineering Corporation of Sri Lanka. The Architectural consultant was Dr. Justin Samarasekara. It was the first hemispherical thin shell build in the country. Almost like a Egg shell. In certain period of times you can view Sri Pada mountain on the nearby bridge. Must see place. Car park is situated in the River Delta.

This is an iconic Stupa, we all pass along the Galle Road heading south. But it is when you go in, that you discover the amazing fact that you can virtually walk inside the Stupa. The echoes bouncing back from walls will continue to echo through your soul. A must visit after worshiping Kalutara Bodhi.

specially on Buddhist holidays you will find a large crowd of local worshippers here. this place is a real original temple and one of the biggest Dagobas in Sri Lanka. You will see it from the mainstreet when riding from Colombo into the south using the beachroad, or from the railwaytracks - Kalutara is where the nice beaches into the south are starting - loving this place and always try to visit it when ever I am in Lanka
There is nothing wrong with looking at the temple like this it is just that if you seen two or three they all begin to look alike

Visited this lovely building and certainly well worth a visit. We both found that it was quite an emotional experience seeing the eternal flame for victims of the tsunami. The building is free to enter but you will be expected to make a small donation (20 rupees) to look after your shoes during your visit. Don't be fooled by 'touts' who unfortunately will show you around but then demand up to 2000 rupees per person. This money doesn't go to the temple it goes straight into their pockets. All in all it was a very good experience and we are glad we visited
This temple is so famous in kalutara. Me and my Family went here to see the beauty and to worship the temple. The temple is  old and big.

Extraordinary temple with a vast stupa. I found the Buddhist teaching from our guide in the area across the road from the temple a little more interesting than the slightly antiseptic interior of the temple itself, although the illustrations of the life of Buddha were fascinating
A great temple located close to river sea and bridge. So beautiful view and so pleasant surrounding . Smell around is really nice. Recommend for all
Temple is located on the main expressway from Colombo to Galle. This can be your first stop point during the drive. How much time you spend matters on yourself.

Kaluthara temple is very famous between locals.there are plenty of activities going on every day.it's so beautiful because of Stupa.you can walk inside.on the top you can find drawings of buddas story.it's so glad to be there.

This Temple is well worth a visit. It's very busy in and around the temple grounds. There are guides offering to give you the tour at a cost, but you can walk around on your own. It's customary to offer a small donation to Buddha .

This temple has two sections, one either side of a busy road, but is connected by subway. The first section requires a donation and you are accompanied by a guide. The guide was very informative. We were accompanied by our rickshaw driver for the second section and he explained much about the temple and the pictures of Buddha and the stories. I learnt more about Buddhism in 30 minutes in this temple than I had learnt in my life before. Thoroughly recommend.

We negotiated 600 rupees from the hotel, 200 under the quoted rate, and lived to arrive at the temple, 6 km journey and 17 near death experiences. A friend of the driver took us in hand and showed us around the temple.  It was very informative but was spoilt when he asked for 5 dollars , 1000 rupees each.  The couple we were with stormed off leaving the temple, I paid 200 rupees, and took the subway under the main road to the largest  Step take (hollow dome) in the World. 34 paintings of Buddha's 3 journeys to Sri Lanka.   Well worth the trip.

We had a really nice visit here which was the main reason for us visiting Kalutara.  We arrived for evening puja and enjoyed wandering around the site, under the subway and inside the dagoba.  The birds roosting at dusk were very memorable.

This temple is located in the middle of the Kaluthara town facing Galle road.However it is a calm and quite place at night.Visitors can walk inside the Kalutara Chaitya to worship .This large concrete dome shell structure was designed by Dr. A. N. S. Kulasinghe .
This place is very beautiful & it belongs to Buddhist temple where you can study more on buddhism. Attracted by many religions

Kalutara is the place where I was born.  So much has changed since -  from the increased traffic to the noise and the pollution - turning the small, peaceful town of Kalutara once was, where I grew up, into a chaotic, restless place. There is a highway runs across the town, making it easier for the drivers to get from place to place , quicker than it used to be. Amid the hustle and the bustle, Buddhists never failed to stop by the Kalutara Bodhi.  The old temple I love to this day. This is the only place I miss since I moved out of Kalutara and  I never fail to visit the temple since. They have made a few changes, yet, the old Bo tree, (a sacred tree) and the old shrine room where there is a very old statue of Buddha, remained just as beautiful as they were many moons ago. This is due to the constant care given by the Buddhist society, in Kalutara.  You feel the power of the Blessings as soon as you step into the temple.  There is also another very big statue of Buddha on the other end of the temple.  Unlike those days, you do not have to risk your life trying to cross the main road to get to the other side of the road, where there is a branch of this ancient temple, that is built on a hire hill. There is a subway to cross the main street. These temples are situated by the famous Kalu river (meaning -black river in Sinhalese), where I used to bath with my Papa, when I was a little girl.  I absolutely adore this place.  I would also like to add, if you are lucky, you might see elephants on the roads, with their carers of course. Hearing the recent news of a man being attacked by an elephant in another country, this is something I always say to people who visit Sri Lanka. Wherever you go, if you see an elephant, do not  run up to it and start taking photographs, flashing the camera light in his eyes.  This disturbs the elephant.  Many years ago, someone dropped a cigarette end in front of the path of the elephants during the main procession in Kandy.  When the elephant stepped on it, he got disturbed.  That day, the elephants ran a riot and killed many people.  Elephants are adorable to look at, they are very important part in our lives, but when you visit these places, respect these animals and the religious places you visit.  You have to remove your shoes and dress appropriately.  Well, I hope many people would visit Kalutara and enjoy the sheer beauty of the nature.  Calico is another place to visit in Kalutara.  Be very careful when you visit this places.  If you go to the near by hotel for a cup of tea, you could see the Kalutara Bodhi from the distance and also, you can stand on the rocks, by the Calico.  I stress, be very careful, because water crazily swirls round the rocks. The photo of the Bodhiya is the temple on the hill, on the other side of the road.  Inside is hollow and massive.  It is decorated with stories of Buddha's life.  There are also statues of Buddha inside.  Takes about half an hour, if you care to read all the information and look at the beautiful paintings on the walls.  I have been there many times in my life time and I will be going again in February 2016.   This is why I selected this date from the drop down list.
Worth a look and read all the stories behind the pictures in the upper dome. Use the under road tunnel to view both sites of the temple

"Kaluthara Bodhiya and Dagaba" is one of the main attractions of people going through the Galle Road. It is situated in the Kalutara District and is one of the main Buddhist shrines in Sri Lanka. The specialty of the Dabada is that, people can go in to the outer Dagaba and there is another small dagaba inside the large one.

This is kalautara bodiya it's wonder of western Provence of sri lanka but its not a true one and only sri lanka "bodiya " you can reach in side the bodiya  amercing place near the Black river world one and only place you can see river starting place and mouth of the ocean

Buddhist temple, looks nice and interesting from outside. The entrance is free, but you have few people standing around waiting for tourist to show them place for tips. ( I know they want to make them living, but if you would tip everywhere even on free public places you wont have much money left) The colours of Buddha are very nice and paintings too. Be prepared to take of your shoes of before you enter in to the temple and make sure that your body its coved with clothes especially women's. There is holy water outside of temple on the side of the road for drivers to stop and have a little blessing for them journey on the road. Cross the road is market with flowers where you can buy them and bring them inside to temple.
My home town. As school kids visited ever day. Since I moved to Gampaha , when I visit my home used to visit & worshipping. I really love the place.

The outside of the temple is quite stunning but the inside let it down a bit - nevertheless worth a visit if you're in the area. There is no entrance fee, so make sure you don't get lulled in by a tout who wants to show you the temple for an exorbitant price  - rather give some money as a donation to the temple.

I would normally rate this sort of thing higher as i love going around places of history, culture and religion however if i am honest it didnt grip me and say yes i would recommend everyone goes here. If you are in the area i would definitely have a wonder round. It is free to go in however you will be expected to make a donation if you ask for them to look after your shoes you may also end up with a guide showing you around and he most certainty will want a tip. Our guide wanted 2000 rupees each which i did find steep so we most certainly brought him down on this. It is beautiful to see the colours of Buddha and the paintings are brilliant. In the courtyard you can see the eternal flames burning for loved ones and can see the great tree. If you wonder under the road you can go into the main temple and walk around at your leisure it is very echoy so be careful not to speak to loud! Outside there are some fantastic views over the river so make sure you have your camera to hand.

visited with my familly ,its the landmark of kaluthara,make me pride as a srilankan..its like jem of srilankan history..also a great architecurel design and construction that its build on river bed..soo beautiful landscaping when you sit on middle of the bridge and looking around..
This temple is huge, really good for intention to detail. A guide came in with us which was very interesting!
Well worth a visit, its massive. Depending at what time of day you go it can be very, vey busy .Its nice to people watch there
this budhist temple is near the bridge where one of largest river flows by. Amazing view from the temple and worth visit.
best place to visit for  mind relaxing peaceful place.. lovely atmosphere and beautiful view will relax and please you..
Free entry but you are expected to make a donation to the shoe lady who looks after your shoes etc You don't need guide or anything, we got the local bus from kalutara to here
Almost crowded area..However calm sit and one of most popular Buddhist site..more crowded in poya days and weekends..
The Kalatura Bodhi is the Buddhist temple where people gather to worship. The sacred Bo Tree is one of the main attractions.
Kalutara is the only church which you can go to Sri Lanka,We took the easiest to with tuk  -tukkal,he river of Sri Lanka's third largest river,the bus station tea is good for business
The temple is well known in Sri Lanka and attracts many pilgrims and visitors. Located on the main Colombo/Galle Road it overlooks the Kalu Kanga River and is close to the centre of Kalutara
"Amazing such a beautiful building ! To read the story of Buddhism Must be seen in the day and night" .

Great place to visit. Very old bo-tree with a giant sthupa. Almost everyone stop at this place if traveling to down south via Galle road. Ample parking is available. Need about 1/2 - 45 mnts to explore the place.

This Buddhist temple is a world renowned place, it has a lovely Bo tree (sacred tree) & a beautiful Stupa where Buddhists love to worship. Beautiful Temple and well worth a visit. Take flowers or buy them outside the temple. Very educating information are available, if you want to know about Buddhism.
Dont pay for entrance,. give a donation into the box or for the official office for placing shoes. Very nice, very calming. excellent views - can see all the way up the river to Adams Peak.

This temple was beautiful and very busy because we were there during the school holidays. We then visited the small museum next to it which has interesting artefacts and a coin collection with coins from different countries.
Went by Tuk-Tuk it was interesting to appreciate other religions. Good guide. Bought flowers as an offering outside for 100 Rupees (50p) in UK money. Would have cost £30 or more in the UK..

we were ripped off by people who told us we needed to pay to enter. You don't have to pay to enter, do NOT pay these people: donations to the temple should be put into the locked boxes available. such a shame we had this experience, the temple was beautiful, serene, well worth a visit - but please learn from our mistake.

We came here knowing it is a free entrance Bodhiya. A guy took us in, showed us everything, told about its history, the tree, the rituals. Then asked quite abruptly for 10 USD so called donation for each person. Since we didn't bring that much money we gave him RS 200 and continued to see the stupa across the road without him. We were told it is the only stupa in Sri lanka you can go inside. There is very nice view, lots of people just browsing or meditating. It is quite calm place even though you can hear the street noise. Definitely worth visiting, just be prepared to take off your shoes and ignore the guide at the entrance.

One is typically dropped off at the other side of the road where a guide is picking up the tourists and shows you this part with the ancient (and beautifull) tree. The guide asked us (quite directive...) to donate 10 usd per person as a donation to the poor. Interesting to see the official desk for donations at the entrance of the temple on the other side of the road. In hindsight we would have preferred to give our donation here.
Fantastic temple, made to feel very welcome and we were even asked to have our photo taken for the school children by their teacher. Really a must see.

When you enter, you are told to take off your shoes. If you are a woman without any cover for your legs, you are given a stinky cloth. Inside, nothing too interesting. Just a lot of candles burning and pigeon poo. I got attacked by one of the pigeons. Inside the dome, it's quite scary. Quite a lot of wasted space really. People walking around in circles for ages and playing drums with others watching.

The bodhiya was build to pay respect to the holy bo tree on the opposite side of the road. It is a unique experience to visit especially in the evening, when it's filled with locals praying and bringing their donations and sacrifices to the Buddha. This is the only bodhiya where you can actually go inside the dome on the top. If you go at daytime, you'll be rewarded by wonderful views of the surroundings. Make sure you visit the garden around the holy tree across the street (use the "sub way")
Beautiful Temple. Well worth a visit. Take flowers or buy them outside the temple. Free to visit, but donations gratefully accepted.
Very helpful guide explained abut the religion.  Spent an hour looking around the temple.  Worth a visit.
This was an amazing experience. It was like being in the whispering gallery with a gallery of paintings all around. Such a wonderful experience and a joy to visit. Please be respectful when visiting

A best view of Indian Ocean and Kalu River. If you are lucky enough you will see the start point of the river (Sri Pada Mountain) when the sky is so clear.So this is a place you can see both the start point and end point of a river.A very sacred buddhist temple so it is better to speak softly and wear light colour full cloths
very Calming and peaceful place (Buddhist religious Place),No entrance fee, you can freely visit and worship
Very beautifull place, big stupa with all the orginal elements. Visit when their is a ceremonie. You can buy at the local market.

the pichture of the dagaba( chaiththiya) you see here is actually hollow and a concret shell.designed by a famed sri lankan engineer. inside yoy find a sall dagaba with relics. the oer sapce inside is similar to maluwa( ( perimeter) of a conventional dagabo, i t can accomadate thousands of people. the picture of the dagaba ( chaiththiya) you see here is actually hollow and a concert shell. Designed by a famed Sri Lankan engineer. Inside you find a small dagaba with relics. The space inside is similar to maluwa  ( perimeter) of a conventional dagaba, it can accommodate thousands of people. There are two bo trees. One beside the road is patronized by many. The other one is at the top of the hill beside the dagaba. It is a very popular bo tree among some Buddhists who believes some Bo trees have more divine attraction than others.

went into Kalutara Bodhiya a few times and although its a busy high street it was a little grubby and also be warned if you want to go to the fish market, take a peg with you, it STINKS!! also be aware a lot of begging and market traders trying to get you to look at their wares and goods, very pushy all the time, put your foot down and be firm and if anything you do like make sure you go into the actual stallholders stall, they will not hassle you. over all the high street not bad, however when you go to the bridges you can see the temples, these are beautiful and although unsure if you can go into the actual temple itself one side of the bridge allows tourists in, you will get a guide and again make sure if you tip them, give them what you think you need to and be firm, one of them tried getting to greedy, I had to tell him in tell him in the end where to go, that's not me but this is what you need to do, I gave £1,000 rupees this was plenty and works out just under £5.00... dont let this put you off, it is really nice in there and a lot of respect for the Buddhists
the great place for buddhist people to worship. this is the biggest bodiya of kalutara. all the sri lankan people respect to this bodiya.
Nice place to spend a few hours very active and a lot of devotees very famous place. nicely located by the side of the river

It is situated on the galle road at Kalutara town.the best time to visit this temple is after 6.00 p.m. the Bo tree is very powerful. If you go and make a wish, 100 % your wish will come true. Specially if you are wishing some body to have good health while he/she is sick, this place will help you.
like food and bevarge,accomodation,staffs dislike the evening entertinment.band was not so good.im asking about evening entertinmnet bcs i like to enjoying the DJ's
This is the best place to visit when we are in problem. The environment in the Bodhiya help to relax our mind and take the good decision after thinking with peaceful mind.

The environment in the Bodhiya is calm & serene, as you settle down on the floor, transcending time & space, looking inward for a brief time, leaving the cares of the world. With a fantastic view of the Ocean, the place is divine.
Fascinating to see all the worshippers, and to walk around between two temples barefoot.  Lots of lights and flashing neon, and streets decorated with flags.
We were in May 2015 there , there was a big Festival with a lot of light and flowers ! Nice experience.

We arrived here the weekend following a full moon, and the queues to go and see the relic were tremendous - hundreds and thousands of Buddhists, all dressed in white and carrying lotus blossoms and lilies. This is the only temple in which you can go inside the dome. Walking around the inside, you can walk round the 75 pictures depicting various scenes important to Buddhism. On the other side of the road (best to use the subway), one of the ladies there gave me an incense stick to burn, another provided me with incense oil. It was beautiful to take part in these rituals. The local people were very kind and explained what was going on. Definitely a must-do if you stop in this town.

This amazing place has an amazing story.... Chances are, if you are in any sort of Tourist Vehicle passing by, the driver will stop without being asked to, get out, put some money into a receptacle, and then get in and drive away again, leaving you wondering! Apparently, almost all drivers stop here at this Temple at the beginning of their journey down south, and put some money into one of the many boxes made for the purpose, as a sort of "prayer" for a safe journey! Seems to work, because very few people have complained that it didn't! Oh, and, it's a really good place to view a magnificient Buddhist Temple first-hand, ask your driver to allow you to spend some time inside, expecially in the evening when it's really beautiful!

We first visited Kalutara in the night and the site of the lite dome was impressive. We went in the temple on both sides of the road and it was surprising to see how 'bare' the main temple is. Great to see at night all thevcandles lit outside under the tree and to smell the incense.

A wonderful place to visit which looks great during the night time with the lights. It is located just next to river Kaluganga. There are two saplings of Sri Mahabodhi from Anuradhapura, planted here on each side of the road. So the temple is on both sides of the road. However the Dome is main attraction for tourists. I have been to some other Buddhist temples in sri Lanka/ Mayanmar/ Indonesia but this is the only dome that i have come across which is empty from inside and you can go in. there is one more dome inside this big one. There also a lot of pictures depicting the life of Buddha and also of his different incarnations. Nice place to visit as it looks really beautiful during the night time. A very calming place with the chanting by the monks in the evening, when I had visited it. A must see in Kalutara. It is on  both sides of the road with and underpass connecting both the sides so that you need not cross the busy road.

This a wonderful place to visit if you are passing by kalutara. Facing the magnificent Kaluganga ( river). If you can visit around 7am or after 5pm you will witness some breath taking views from the kalutara bodhiya. Do not forget to walk into the kalutara bodhiya. The uniqueness of this temple is you can walk into the pagoda. Its a wonderful experiance believe me. As it is religious place always remeber to where a decent attire.
The only Bhuddist Sutra (dome) that is hollow inside, well worth a look, incorporate it in a trip to the black river or to Bevis Bauers home
watch out for the fake guides- you dont need a guide... its pretty striaght forwards but remember to remove your shoes

This is situated at the entrance of the city of Kalutara which is about 35 KM from Colombo there are ample public transport from Colombo Bus will more easier it will not cost even $ .50 cents. This teple is standing just by the side of the Colombo Galle road. This place is worshiped  by all Buddhist people.  All  are permitted to can go in to the temple. On one side you have the Bo tree and the temple other side the temple and the Tagoba (The big white dome), a specialty here is that you can go into the Tagoba. Please note there is no entry fees or donations to any one if you want you can put it into the box or the temple office(don't give to any individual) . There is a place for you to leave your foot wear so don't go to shops and kiosk and be cheated.  In my view you don't need a tour guide to this site you can manage by your self there is a beautiful river by the side of the temple and a beach close by. There is a tunnel crossing you can use to cross the busy road. Please be decently dressed no shorts and mini skirts are allowed.

Kalutara Bodhiya is located centrally right where the bridge is starting at Kalutara South End. Spread across both side of the road, this is a spiritual Buddhist temple. Main prayer hall is a majestic circular hall and a definite visit in Kalutara. However, travellers beware that this is the only place in my entire Sri Lanka trip where people tried to scam and never expected the same inside Buddhist temple. On entry, one person offered to explain the place as a tour guide. In the end of the visit, he introduced to one person and saying that tomorrow is full moon and there will be prayer and offering at the temple, asked for USD  5 to give. I offered him LKR 100 sensing something amiss and this was a scam as the 2nd person was a complete outsider in connivance with the tour guide. At the end of the tour, the guide himself was asking for money and again the kiosk which was keeping shoes asking for money. I am ok offering money to the persons keeping shoes and also the guide explaining but the guide himself will scam in a Buddhist temple in the name of offering to God in full moon day is really bad!! Please note donation is accepted in all temples but always put the same in donation box and not to anyone directly.

The temple was very interesting - the big one that is.  There is a smaller one across the road, but be careful. There is a gentleman who directs you there and tells you the only way to big Bodiya is from tunnel under the road. But he is directing you to the people who want you to pay them to look after your slippers and show you round.  The temple has big signs signing no entrance fee should be paid, only donations.  Make a generous donation instead.

This serene temple situated on Galle Road in Kalutara and we saw many drivers stopped their cars and stopped over here for worship prior to continuing their journeys. There was a large stupa and a bo tree.  We were very interested at the inside of the stupa.  The place was really peaceful and quiet and good for meditation.  Recommend you to visit this temple on the way to Colombo. The temple was properly maintained through the purposely set up fund and you can donate the sum for goodwill.
It is good to visit on Poya day (full moon) when many locals attend and the atmosphere is very good with most of the ladies wearing white.
Clean and well maintained temple. Good place for meditation. View from the upper temple is extremely picturesque.

In keeping with the Buddhist culture. Beautiful to look at and pilgrims who had come to worship added to the special place tourists were admiring. The oil lamps and offerings of flowers at the temple provided a very Eastern atmosphere. Architecturally pleasing and somewhere which is well worth seeing and part of the land.

Kaluthara Bodhiya is a Buddhist temple. The temple is located in a very beautiful location which opposite of the Kaluthara river. There you can enter to inside the pagoda. There you can see Ananda Bodhiya which is son tree of Sri Maha bodhiya, Anuradhapura.
This  Buddhist temple is  a world reknown place, it has a lovely Bo tree(sacred tree) & a beautiful Stupa where Buddhists love to worship  . The temple is situated on the  Galle Rd in Kalutara.

This Buddhist temple is on your way out of Colombo to the south of Srilanka.You will never miss as all Srilankan drivers will stop and pray for a safe journey.You must  get down have look.Its one of the famous Buddhist temple in Srilanka.
Got to visit this place if you are in the area.  A must. Very educating, if you want to know about Buddhism.
